As the Programming Lead for the GP-3 project at Future Games, I handled the communication between the disciplines while also taking on significant responsibilities in gameplay programming. My contributions included developing key gameplay features such as Projectile Trajectories / Throwing and the implementation of the Key-to-Gate system, while also making sure the game is delivered with no major performance flaws.

Parabolic-Function based throwing -> Tldr

Using a parabolic function, calculate the path that the projectile should take when traveling towards the target point. Also added a UFlotCurve as a size determination on the trajectory line. When the player shoots, the projectile receives the trajectory points and travels through them. When the desired hit point isn't possible, the curve turns red.

Curve

The trajectory curve is created by performing a "raycast" from the player to the mouse position to determine the target point. A series of points are generated between the start and end points, with adjusted heights to form a parabolic path, and these points are visualized with trajectory meshes.

Projectiles

When the player spawns a projectile or shoots, the projectile receives the trajectory point positions. It then utilizes these positions as the travel destinations. By checking the distance between the current position and the next point in the curve, we can smoothly and reliably make it travel where we want.

Key to doors -> Tldr

The key idles, when the player approaches and gets within the set radius, it switches states and starts following the player. When the key gets within the target range from a door it will open the door and play the necessary timelien animations..
